title: Marked + WSX Custom Renderer Demo
description: This demo shows how to override marked's default renderer with WSX components to create custom, interactive Markdown rendering.
sampleMarkdown:
# Welcome to Marked + WSX

This is a **demonstration** of how to use `marked` with custom WSX renderers.

## Features

- Custom heading rendering with WSX components
- Enhanced code blocks with syntax highlighting
- Custom blockquotes with styled components
- Interactive lists with WSX components

### Code Example

```javascript
// This is a code block
function greet(name) {
    return `Hello, ${name}!`;
}
```

> This is a blockquote demonstrating custom rendering

### Lists

1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item

- Unordered item
- Another item

### Links and Images

Check out [WSXJS](https://wsxjs.dev) for more information.

---

**Bold text** and *italic text* are also supported.

pattern1.title: Pattern 1:
pattern1.description: Using marked.use({ renderer }) - Renderer returns HTML strings with WSX custom element tags

pattern2.label: Pattern 2
pattern2.title: Pattern 2:
pattern2.description: Using marked.lexer() + Manual WSX JSX rendering - Returns actual JSX elements

pattern1.title: Pattern 1: marked.use({ renderer })
pattern1.description: Create a custom renderer object that returns HTML strings containing WSX custom element tags. Since WSX components are registered as custom elements, they work when inserted as HTML.
pattern1.cons: Returns HTML strings, not JSX elements

pattern2.title: Pattern 2: marked.lexer() + WSX JSX
pattern2.description: Use marked.lexer() to get tokens, then manually convert them to WSX JSX elements. This allows returning actual JSX elements instead of HTML strings.
pattern2.pros: Returns actual JSX elements, fully type-safe
pattern2.cons: More manual work, need to handle all token types

components.title: WSX Components
components.description: Both patterns use the same WSX Web Components. The components are registered as custom elements, so they work in both HTML strings (Pattern 1) and JSX (Pattern 2).

typeSafety.label: Type Safety:
typeSafety.description: Full TypeScript support for renderer methods

reusability.label: Component Reusability:
reusability.description: Reuse WSX components across different renderer methods

interactivity.label: Interactivity:
interactivity.description: Add event handlers and reactive state to rendered elements

styleIsolation.label: Style Isolation:
styleIsolation.description: Web Components provide automatic style scoping

maintainability.label: Maintainability:
maintainability.description: Clean, declarative JSX syntax instead of string concatenation
